sen.j: 高倉 福信（たかくら の ふくしん、709年（和銅2年） - 789年11月3日（延暦8年10月8日 (旧暦)））は奈良時代の公卿。
sen.e: TAKAKURA no Fukushin (709 - November 3, 789) was a court noble who lived during the Nara period.
TAKAKURA no Fukushin (709 - November 3, 789) was a court noble who lived during the Nara period.
TAKAKURA no Fukushin (709 - November 3, 789) was a court noble who lived during the Nara period.

sen.j: 高句麗王族の背奈福徳の孫で背奈福光の子。
sen.e: His father was SENA no Fukumitsu and his grandfather was SENA no Fukutoku, a member of the Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea) royal family.
His father was SENA no Fukumitsu and his grandfather was SENA no Fukutoku, a member of the Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea) royal family.
His father was SENA no Fukumitsu and his grandfather was SENA no Fukutoku, a member of the Goguryeo (kingdom of Korea) royal family.

sen.j: 万葉集背奈行文の甥にあたる。
sen.e: His uncle was SENA no Yukifumi, whose poem appears in the Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).
His uncle was SENA no Yukifumi, whose poem appears in the Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).
His uncle was SENA no Yukifumi, whose poem appears in the Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).

sen.j: 従三位・造宮省・弾正台・武蔵国国司。
sen.e: He was appointed Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank), Zogusho (Ministry of Making and Mending Palaces), Danjodai (Board of Censors), and Musashi no kuni no kami (Governor of Musashi Province).

His court rank was Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank), and he was appointed as Minister of Zogusho (Ministry of Making and Mending Palaces), Director of Danjodai (Board of Censors), and Musashi no kuni no kami (Governor of Musashi Province).
sen.cmt: 人が主語の文でappointedの後に続く語は役職名であるべきところ、訳文は原文の直訳で団体名Zogusho Danjodai となっておりおます。調べた範囲ではこれらの団体の長官としての功績があるようですので、原文とは少し離れますが役職名を追加し書き換えました。また従三位は官位であり、役職とは併記しないほうが良いように思われますので文頭を書き換えました。
sen.e: His court rank was Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank), and he was appointed as Minister of Zogusho (Ministry of Making and Mending Palaces), Director of Danjodai (Board of Censors), and Musashi no kuni no kami (Governor of Musashi Province).

sen.j: 武蔵国高麗郡出身で、初め背奈公福信と名乗った。
sen.e: According to the "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), he was born in Koma County, Musashi Province and originally called himself Sena no Ko Fukushin.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処 背奈公福信の読み不明
sen.e: According to the "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), he was born in Koma County, Musashi Province and originally called himself Sena no Ko Fukushin.
According to the "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), he was born in Koma County, Musashi Province and originally called himself Sena no Ko Fukushin.

sen.j: 叔父の背奈行文を頼り、上洛したという（『続日本紀』）。
sen.e: He went up to the capital, seeking support from his uncle, SENA no Yukifumi (according to the "Shoku Nihongi").
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He went up to the capital, seeking support from his uncle, SENA no Yukifumi (according to the "Shoku Nihongi"[Chronicle of Japan Continued]).
sen.cmt: 『続日本紀』：初出のため[Chronicle of Japan Continued]を追加
sen.e: He went up to the capital, seeking support from his uncle, SENA no Yukifumi (according to the "Shoku Nihongi"[Chronicle of Japan Continued]).

sen.j: 相撲の名人で同輩と石上衢で相撲を取ったところ評判を呼び、その武勇を称えた聖武天皇の内豎所に召されたという。
sen.e: It is said that he excelled at Sumo so well that a bout he had fought at Isonokami no Chimata (the junction in Isonokami) became the talk of the town, leading to being invited to the Naijudokoro (Royal Pages Office) by Emperor Shomu, who was impressed by his outstanding performance.

It is said that he excelled at Sumo so well that a bout he had fought with his colleague at Isonokami no Chimata (the junction in Isonokami) became the talk of the town, leading to being invited to the Naijudokoro (Royal Pages Office) by Emperor Shomu, who was impressed by his outstanding performance.
sen.cmt: 同輩と:訳抜けのためfoughtの後に with his colleague追加。 Invited の前の過剰スペースを削除。
sen.e: It is said that he excelled at Sumo so well that a bout he had fought with his colleague at Isonokami no Chimata (the junction in Isonokami) became the talk of the town, leading to being invited to the Naijudokoro (Royal Pages Office) by Emperor Shomu, who was impressed by his outstanding performance.

sen.j: 右衛士大志を経た後に天平10年（738年）に従六位から外従五位下、翌年には従五位を経た後、天平15年（743年）には正五位・春宮亮となる。
sen.e: After serving as a Ueji no daishi (Senior Assistant Lieutenant of the Right Guards), he was promoted from the rank of Jurokui (Junior Sixth Rank) to Gejugoinoge (Jugoinoge [Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade] given to persons outside Kyoto) in 738, and then was awarded the rank of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) in the following year, and appointed to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) and Togu no suke (Assistant Master of the Crown Prince's Quarters) in 743.

After serving as a Ueji no daishi (Senior Assistant Lieutenant of the Right Guards), he was promoted from the rank of Jurokui (Junior Sixth Rank) to Gejugoinoge (Jugoinoge [Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade] given to persons outside Kyoto) in 738, and then was awarded the rank of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) in the following year, and appointed to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) and Togu no suke (Assistant Master of the Crown Prince's Quarters) in 743.

After serving as a Ueji no daishi (Senior Assistant Lieutenant of the Right Guards), he was promoted from the rank of Jurokui (Junior Sixth Rank) to Gejugoinoge (Jugoinoge [Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade] given to persons outside Kyoto) in 738, and then was awarded the rank of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) in the following year, and appointed to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) and Togu no suke (Assistant Master of the Crown Prince's Quarters) in 743.

sen.j: 天平19年（747年）には同族7名とともに背奈王（せなのこにきし）の姓を授けられ、背奈王福信と名乗る。
sen.e: In 747, together with other seven members of his family, he was given a surname of Sena no Konikishi and called himself SENA no Konikishi Fukushin.
In 747, together with other seven members of his family, he was given a surname of Sena no Konikishi and called himself SENA no Konikishi Fukushin.
In 747, together with other seven members of his family, he was given a surname of Sena no Konikishi and called himself SENA no Konikishi Fukushin.

sen.j: 翌年には正五位上に叙せられた。
sen.e: He was awarded the rank of Shogoinojo (Senior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) in the following year.
He was awarded the rank of Shogoinojo (Senior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) in the following year.
He was awarded the rank of Shogoinojo (Senior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) in the following year.

sen.j: 天平勝宝元年（749年）に従四位下中衛少将兼紫微中台少弼となり、更に正四位下に昇進した。
sen.e: In 749, he assumed the post of Chue no shosho (Minor Captain of the Imperial Guard) of Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and Shibichudai shohitsu (Assistant Director of the office handling the principal empress Komyo's affairs), and further promoted to the rank of Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade).

In 749, he assumed the post of Chue no shosho (Minor Captain of the Imperial Guard) of Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and Shibichudai shohitsu (Assistant Director of the office handling the principal empress Komyo's affairs), and further promoted to the rank of Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade).

In 749, he assumed the post of Chue no shosho (Minor Captain of the Imperial Guard) of Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and Shibichudai shohitsu (Assistant Director of the office handling the principal empress Komyo's affairs), and further promoted to the rank of Shoshiinoge (Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade).

sen.j: これは長年仕えて来た孝謙天皇即位の功績であると考えられている。
sen.e: This is believed to have been attributable to the enthronement of Empress Koken, whom he had been serving for many years.
This is believed to have been attributable to the enthronement of Empress Koken, whom he had been serving for many years.
This is believed to have been attributable to the enthronement of Empress Koken, whom he had been serving for many years.

sen.j: 天平勝宝2年（750年）、高麗朝臣の姓を授けられ、高麗福信と改める。
sen.e: In 750, he was given a surname of Koma Ason and changed his name to KOMA no Fukushin.
In 750, he was given a surname of Koma Ason and changed his name to KOMA no Fukushin.
In 750, he was given a surname of Koma Ason and changed his name to KOMA no Fukushin.

sen.j: 天平勝宝8年（756年）に聖武上皇崩御に伴い山作司に任じられ、同年山背守から武蔵守に遷任した。
sen.e: On the death of the retired Emperor Shomu in 756, he was appointed Yamatsukuri no Tsukasa (Official in charge of building the mausoleum) and was transferred from the post of Yamashiro no kami (Governor of Yamashiro Province) to Musashi no kami (Governor of Musashi Province) in the same year.

On the death of the retired Emperor Shomu in 756, he was appointed Yamatsukuri no Tsukasa (Official in charge of building the mausoleum) and was transferred from the post of Yamashiro no kami (Governor of Yamashiro Province) to Musashi no kami (Governor of Musashi Province) in the same year.

On the death of the retired Emperor Shomu in 756, he was appointed Yamatsukuri no Tsukasa (Official in charge of building the mausoleum) and was transferred from the post of Yamashiro no kami (Governor of Yamashiro Province) to Musashi no kami (Governor of Musashi Province) in the same year.

sen.j: 武蔵守の在任時には、当時工事が滞って未完成だった国分寺を僅かの間で築き終え、天平宝字2年（756年）武蔵国内に新座郡を設置している。
sen.e: During his service as Musashi no kami (Governor of Musashi Province), he promptly finished construction of Kokubun-ji Temple, which had been behind schedule, and, in 756, built Niikura district in the Province.

During his service as Musashi no kami (Governor of Musashi Province), he promptly finished construction of Kokubun-ji Temple, which had been behind schedule, and, in 756, built Niikura district in the Province.

During his service as Musashi no kami (Governor of Musashi Province), he promptly finished construction of Kokubun-ji Temple, which had been behind schedule, and, in 756, built Niikura district in the Province.

sen.j: なお、福信は霊亀元年（715年）の高麗郡設置以来、同郡の郡司であった高麗若光（およびその一族）と同族と考えられており、福信自身も同国内に大きな影響力を持っていたとみられている。
sen.e: It is said that KOMA no Jakko (and his family), who had been serving as a local magistrate of Koma County since the county's formation in 715, was Fukushin's family member and Fukushin himself had a powerful influence over the province.

It is said that KOMA no Jakko (and his family), who had been serving as a local magistrate of Koma County since the county's formation in 715, was Fukushin's family member and Fukushin himself had a powerful influence over the province.

It is said that KOMA no Jakko (and his family), who had been serving as a local magistrate of Koma County since the county's formation in 715, was Fukushin's family member and Fukushin himself had a powerful influence over the province.

sen.j: 天平宝字2年（757年）正四位に叙せられ、天平宝字4年（760年）に信部大輔（中務大輔）に任ぜられる。
sen.e: In 757, he was given the rank of Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) and then appointed Shinbu no taifu/Nakatsukasa no taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs) in 760.
In 757, he was given the rank of Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) and then appointed Shinbu no taifu/Nakatsukasa no taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs) in 760.
In 757, he was given the rank of Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) and then appointed Shinbu no taifu/Nakatsukasa no taifu (Senior Assistant Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs) in 760.

sen.j: 道鏡政権下の天平神護元年（765年）に従三位となり公卿に列した。
sen.e: Under Dokyo's government in 765, he was awarded the rank of Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) and raised to the nobility.
Under Dokyo's government in 765, he was awarded the rank of Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) and raised to the nobility.
Under Dokyo's government in 765, he was awarded the rank of Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) and raised to the nobility.

sen.j: 神護景雲元年（767年）に造宮卿兼法王宮職大夫となる。
sen.e: In 765, he took up the post of Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces) and Hoogushiki daibu (Master of the domestic governing institution for Dokyo).
In 767, he took up the post of Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces) and Hoogushiki daibu (Master of the domestic governing institution for Dokyo).
In 767, he took up the post of Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces) and Hoogushiki daibu (Master of the domestic governing institution for Dokyo).

sen.j: 宝亀元年（770年）の称徳天皇崩御の際には御装束司を務め、2度目の武蔵守となる。
sen.e: He served as a Goshozokushi (an official handling important rituals) when Emperor Shotoku died in 770 and was appointed Musashi no kami again.
He served as a Goshozokushi (an official handling important rituals) when Emperor Shotoku died in 770 and was appointed Musashi no kami again.
He served as a Goshozokushi (an official handling important rituals) when Emperor Shotoku died in 770 and was appointed Musashi no kami again.

sen.j: 翌年、武蔵国が東山道から東海道に移されているが、当時の守であった福信が関与していると言われている。
sen.e: He is said to have been involved in the following year's relocation of Musashi Province from Tosando to Tokaido.

In the following year, the administrative affiliation of Musashi Province with Tosando was transferred to Tokaido, and Fukushin is said to have been involved in this event as the governor of the province.
sen.cmt: 当時の守であった:訳抜け 行政区分の所属が「移され」たのであり土地そのものが移動したわけではないのでrelocateは不自然かもしれません。念のため書き換えました。また、ここでは東海道や東山道が経路だけでなくそれを基にした一種の行政区画であったことを表す説明があったほうがより良いと思われますが、ここでは追加していません。
sen.e: In the following year, the administrative affiliation of Musashi Province with Tosando was transferred to Tokaido, and Fukushin is said to have been involved in this event as the governor of the province.

sen.j: 宝亀4年（773年）、造宮卿としての功績で嫡男高倉石麻呂が替わりに従五位下を授けられた。
sen.e: In 773, Fukushin's legitimate son, TAKAKURA no Ishimaro, was awarded the rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) for the achievements Fukushin made as the Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces).

In 773, Fukushin's legitimate son, TAKAKURA no Ishimaro, was awarded the rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) for the achievements Fukushin made as the Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces).

In 773, Fukushin's legitimate son, TAKAKURA no Ishimaro, was awarded the rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) for the achievements Fukushin made as the Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces).

sen.j: 宝亀7年（776年）の造宮卿兼近江守となる。
sen.e: In 776, he was appointed to the position of Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces) and Omi no kami (Governor of Omi Province).
In 776, he was appointed to the position of Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces) and Omi no kami (Governor of Omi Province).
In 776, he was appointed to the position of Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces) and Omi no kami (Governor of Omi Province).

sen.j: 宝亀10年（779年）、高倉朝臣の姓を授けられ、高倉福信と改める。
sen.e: In 779, he was given a surname of Takakura Ason and changed his name to TAKAKURA no Fukushin.
In 779, he was given a surname of Takakura Ason and changed his name to TAKAKURA no Fukushin.
In 779, he was given a surname of Takakura Ason and changed his name to TAKAKURA no Fukushin.

sen.j: 天応元年（781年）に弾正尹に遷り、光仁上皇崩御に伴い山作司に任じられる。
sen.e: In 781, he was transferred to the post of Danjoin (President of the Board of Censors) and was appointed Yamatsukuri no Tsukasa (Official in charge of building the mausoleum) on the death of the retired Emperor Konin.

In 781, he was transferred to the post of Danjoin (President of the Board of Censors) and was appointed Yamatsukuri no Tsukasa (Official in charge of building the mausoleum) on the death of the retired Emperor Konin.

In 781, he was transferred to the post of Danjoin (President of the Board of Censors) and was appointed Yamatsukuri no Tsukasa (Official in charge of building the mausoleum) on the death of the retired Emperor Konin.

sen.j: 延暦2年（783年）武蔵守を兼任となり、3度目の武蔵守に任ぜられるが、2年後に致仕。
sen.e: He was appointed to the post of Musashi no kami (Governor of Musashi Province) again for the third time in 783 but resigned two years after that.
He was appointed to the post of Musashi no kami (Governor of Musashi Province) again for the third time in 783 but resigned two years after that.
He was appointed to the post of Musashi no kami (Governor of Musashi Province) again for the third time in 783 but resigned two years after that.

sen.j: 4年後に死去。
sen.e: He died four years later in 789.
He died four years later in 789.
He died four years later in 789.

sen.j: 享年81。
sen.e: He was 81 years old.
He was 81 years old.
He was 81 years old.

sen.j: 渡来人系の地方豪族の出身でありながら孝謙（称徳）天皇の側近として、橘諸兄・藤原仲麻呂・道鏡の各政権で要職を占めながら失脚することなく桓武天皇の時代まで活躍した異色の人物であった。
sen.e: He was extraordinary in that, coming from a powerful local family of Korean descent, he served Emperor Koken (Shotoku) as well as assuming several important posts under each government of TACHIBANA no Moroe, FUJIWARA no Nakamaro, and Dokyo and remained in power throughout the time Emperor Kammu assumed the throne.

He was extraordinary in that, coming from a powerful local family descended from toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese), he served Emperor Koken (Shotoku) as well as assuming several important posts under each government of TACHIBANA no Moroe, FUJIWARA no Nakamaro, and Dokyo and remained in power throughout the time Emperor Kammu assumed the throne.
sen.cmt: 「渡来人系」がof Korean descentとなっており、事実と合致していますが、原文とは少し離れるかと思われましたので、用語集をベースとした語句を用いた表現に変更しました
sen.e: He was extraordinary in that, coming from a powerful local family descended from toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese), he served Emperor Koken (Shotoku) as well as assuming several important posts under each government of TACHIBANA no Moroe, FUJIWARA no Nakamaro, and Dokyo and remained in power throughout the time Emperor Kammu assumed the throne.

sen.j: 子の石麻呂は武蔵介・美作介などを務めた。
sen.e: His son, Ishimaro, assumed several posts, including Musashi no suke (Assistant Governor of Musashi Province) and Mimasaka no suke (Assistant Governor of Mimasaka Province).
His son, Ishimaro, assumed several posts, including Musashi no suke (Assistant Governor of Musashi Province) and Mimasaka no suke (Assistant Governor of Mimasaka Province).
His son, Ishimaro, assumed several posts, including Musashi no suke (Assistant Governor of Musashi Province) and Mimasaka no suke (Assistant Governor of Mimasaka Province).
